seo.h1: Regenerative Shoulder Pain Treatment in London

bodyLocation: Rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
schema.howPerformed: Under live ultrasound or fluoroscopy guidance, we target your specific shoulder problem: (1) For rotator cuff tears or tendinopathy—concentrated PRP or BMAC is injected precisely into the damaged tendon to trigger healing; (2) For subacromial bursitis—anti-inflammatory injection into the bursa combined with PRP; (3) For frozen shoulder—hydrodilatation (controlled saline distension) breaks adhesions followed by steroid and PRP; (4) For calcific tendinitis—percutaneous needling breaks up deposits with ultrasound guidance. Local anesthetic ensures comfort. The procedure takes 30-45 minutes and you'll receive a customized physio protocol before leaving
schema.preparation: Stop anti-inflammatory medications (ibuprofen, aspirin) one week before if safe. Avoid blood-thinning supplements. Wear loose-fitting clothing that allows easy shoulder access. Bring any recent MRI or ultrasound reports. Eat beforehand. Come ready for a sling for 24-48 hours post-procedure. Plan light activities only for 2-3 days after—no lifting or reaching overhead initially
schema.followup: Wear the provided sling for comfort for 24-48 hours but begin gentle pendulum exercises within 24 hours as instructed. Apply ice for 15 minutes every few hours on day one. Avoid lifting anything heavy for 2 weeks. Begin prescribed band exercises and scapular stabilization work at week 2-3. Progress to strengthening under physio guidance at week 4-6. Most people return to desk work within 2-3 days, manual work after 2 weeks. Attend your 6-week and 12-week reviews to assess range of motion, strength, and return to activity. Maintenance may include occasional booster injections
schema.outcome: Over 4-8 weeks, shoulder pain steadily improves as inflammation calms and tissue regenerates. Range of motion increases—you can lift arm overhead, reach behind back, and sleep on that side again without waking. Strength returns for lifting, throwing, and racquet sports. For frozen shoulder, mobility improves dramatically, often avoiding the 18-24 month natural recovery timeline. Many patients avoid surgery entirely. Results last 12-18 months. Rotator cuff tissue is genuinely stronger—not just symptom-masked
schema.medicationRequired: Local anesthetic injection at treatment site. Optional nitrous oxide (laughing gas) for anxious patients
schema.treatmentFrequency: 1-3 sessions depending on severity and condition. Rotator cuff tendinopathy often responds to single treatment. Frozen shoulder may need 2-3 sessions (hydrodilatation + PRP) spaced 6-8 weeks apart
schema.adverseOutcome: Soreness and stiffness for 3-7 days (normal healing response). Small bruise at injection site. Temporary reduction in range of motion for first few days. Very rarely, infection (we use strict sterile technique) or worsening stiffness in frozen shoulder cases
contraindication: Complete full-thickness rotator cuff tear requiring surgical repair
Taking blood thinners (warfarin) without medical clearance
Severe arthritis with no remaining joint space (may need joint replacement)
typicalTest: MRI or ultrasound imaging of shoulder to assess tears and inflammation
Physical examination including range of motion, strength testing, and impingement tests
Medical history including work activities and sports
Pain provocation tests (Hawkins-Kennedy, Neer, drop arm)
clinicalFindings: Rotator cuff tendinopathy or partial-thickness tears
